Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
Can we add restrictions to what nodes can connect in a private and permissioned solution other than .conf settings?

Can CC or daemon be used to verify/execute  upon connection.  Eg CC or cmd line options, CONNECT costs COIN for connecting to join network?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: you can use connect=0 then addnode to only the IP's you want.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: other than that, you would need to firewall the ports to allow only required IP's.

Author: sœÜldat#8733
jl777c#5810
Content: each cluster builds in the ability to import coins burned from another chain in the cluster

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so to go from A -> B (both in the same cluster), you first burn (or lock) the coins in A with a destination of B. Then B can verify that this burn on A was dont properly via the MoMoM mechanism (dont worry about details for a high level explanation), so B then creates new coins that match what was burned in A.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: reduce A  coin by X, increase B coin by X -> total supply in the cluster remains the same

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is this burn protocol that is enabled via MoMoM that allows a cluster of chains to act as a single one

Author: sœÜldat#8733
Content: Wow ok.. and how fingerprints are sent back to all chains ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is built into the (now extended)notarization process. with each notarization each chain sends in a MoM. That allows the komodod to know and be able to prove all transactions on that chain, and more importantly it can create a MoMoM to also be included in the notarization. This communcation loop is time shifted, so for notarization at time X, the MoM of time X is sent along with MoMoM for time X-1

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is a simplification, but I hope gets the idea across. there are some nice graphics that explain this

Author: sœÜldat#8733
Content: And this communication loop cannot create an overflow of resources that could hinder notarization in a long term ?

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: The Notary Node Servers are intend to be run not on just single server, but on multiple as I remember from old conversations as the scaling hit to it.

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: means each notary node operator will most probably have to manage multiple servers.

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: number of notaries will remain same. 64. it's just the resources will be divided into more servers for each.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://komodoplatform.com/komodo-platforms-new-scalability-tech/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that article has nice graphics, etc.

Author: sœÜldat#8733
Content: Perfect I'll do my homework üòÉ thanks for your answers

Author: nobby#8396
Content: @jl777c the scammer‚Äôs name is now ‚Äúpistdov‚Äù just so you know.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you could make a custom eval function that queries oracles and controls behavior based on that

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: EVAL function also on blockheight or any other evaluation (even centralized feed) and then execute accordingly.  CCs don't happen automatically, they must be triggered by a transaction to set them "live" from what i understand.  once they have been started, then the blockheight example will check every block to see if it has the right conditions to be executed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it does require writing custom functions, but in theory most anything is possible. we are working on a demo of a simple card game as a first step to better understanding the things needed to make CC easier to use

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: actually, the custom function is part of the consensus rules as all nodes need to validate the outcomes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: writing consensus code is not for weekend coders, that only leads to troubles. I think we will need to make working templates and then allow people to tweak the parameters and not have to do actual coding. even that is pretty dangerous

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anyone can create a new chain with buggy code, but whether people would actually use it, that is up to them

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: remember each custom eval is embedded in a specific independent chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: being an independent chain it is independent of all the other chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it can destroy itself and no other chain would even know

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well, i guess if you were doing atomic swaps with that chain, that is the only impact

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: code isolation

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: having a system that allows anybody to deploy code that affects everybody... this is pretty brave (or insane)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: presumably all the chains in the cluster are running the same contracts, so a bug in any one of them is a bug in all of them anyway

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: though I guess it is possible to run a different set of contracts on different chains in the cluster... so yes, at scale we end up with interaction issues

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are working on limited life contracts, so maybe things can be setup so it expires. that would avoid the need for hardforking to change an existing one. but if a chain wants to hardfork, it can and since it is independent...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: isolation of code is a time tested method of limiting damage from bugs
